  • In the context of styles or fashions, 样式 is more appropriate.

Common Mistakes:

  • Confusing 样子 (appearance) with 样式 (style).
  • Using 这样 or 那样 incorrectly when referring to physical objects instead of manners or ways.

道.examples:
道 (dào) way, path, road, principle, moral

  • 道路 (dàolù) road, path
  • 道德 (dàodé) moral, ethics
  • 道理 (dàolǐ) reason, rationale, principle
  • 道歉 (dàoqiàn) to apologize
  • 道家 (dàojiā) Taoism
  • 一条道走到黑 (yī tiáo dào zǒu dào hēi) to go down the wrong path

道 has a broad range of meanings, from a physical path or road, to philosophical and moral principles. It is often used in compound words related to ethics, reasoning, and the Taoist philosophy.

Nuances:

  • When referring to a physical path or road, 路 is more commonly used than 道.
  • In the phrase 一条道走到黑, 道 refers to a figurative path or course of action that leads to negative consequences.
  • 道德 specifically refers to moral principles and ethics, while 道理 is more about reasoning and rationale.

Common mistakes:

  • Confusing the philosophical and physical meanings of 道.
  • Overusing 道 when referring to physical paths or roads, where 路 would be more appropriate.

作.examples:
作 (zuò) verb: to do, to make, to write, to act as

  • 作品 (zuòpǐn) work, opus, production
  • 工作 (gōngzuò) work, job, employment
  • 作用 (zuòyòng) to act on, to function, effect, function
  • 作者 (zuòzhě) author, writer
  • 作文 (zuòwén) to write a composition, essay
  • 作业 (zuòyè) homework, assignment
  • 作弊 (zuòbì) to cheat, to commit fraud

作 is a very common verb that can express creating, making, or doing something. It is often used in compound words related to work, writing, or creative pursuits.

Nuances:

  • When referring to a job or occupation, 工作 is more common than just 作.
  • 作为 (zuòwéi) can mean "to act as" or "in the capacity of".
  • Common mistakes: Confusing 作业 (homework) with 工作 (work/job).

种.examples:
种 (zhǒng) kind, type, variety, seed, breed, race

  • 种类 (zhǒnglèi) kind, type, variety, category
  • 种子 (zhǒngzi) seed
  • 品种 (pǐnzhǒng) breed, variety, species
  • 种族 (zhǒngzú) race, ethnic group
  • 种植 (zhòngzhí) to plant, to grow, to cultivate
  • 种田 (zhòngtiān) to farm, to cultivate land

种 is a versatile character that is often used to refer to different kinds, types, varieties, or categories of things, as well as seeds, breeds, and races. It is also used in compound words related to planting and cultivation.

Nuances:

  • When referring to categories or types, 种类 is more common than just 种.
  • 品种 is more specific to breeds or varieties of plants, animals, or products.
  • 种族 is used exclusively for races or ethnic groups.
  • Common mistakes include misusing 种 for other meanings of "type" or "kind" when more specific terms would be more appropriate.

总.examples:
总 (zǒng) total, overall, always, chief, head

  • 总数 (zǒngshù) total number, sum
  • 总是 (zǒngshì) always, invariably
  • 总经理 (zǒngjīnglǐ) general manager, CEO
  • 总共 (zǒnggòng) in total, altogether
  • 总结 (zǒngjié) to summarize, to sum up
  • 总的来说 (zǒngdelàishuō) generally speaking, on the whole

总 is often used to indicate the overall, total, or complete aspect of something. It can also refer to a chief, head, or leader.

Nuances:

  • When referring to a total quantity or sum, 总数 is more specific than just 总.
  • In the context of a company or organization, 总经理 is the most common term for the chief executive or general manager.
  • To express an action that occurs habitually or without exception, 总是 is stronger and more emphatic than just 总.

Common mistakes:

  • Not distinguishing between 总是 (always) and 总的来说 (generally speaking).
  • Using 总 alone when referring to a specific total or sum, instead of 总数.

从.examples:
从 (cóng) from, follow, obey, join, engage in

  • 从哪里来 (cóng nǎlǐ lái) where are you from
  • 从小 (cóngxiǎo) from a young age
  • 从今以后 (cóngjīnyǐhòu) from now on
  • 从头再来 (cóngtóuzàilái) to start over again
  • 从事 (cóngshì) to engage in, to pursue (a profession)
  • 从军 (cóngjūn) to join the army
  • 从中 (cóngzhōng) from among
  • 从属 (cóngshǔ) to belong to, to be subordinate to

从 is a versatile word with multiple meanings. It can indicate the starting point of an action or event, the source or origin, or the act of following or obeying. It's also used in various idiomatic expressions.

Nuances:

  • When used with a location, 从 indicates the starting point of a movement or journey.
  • When used with a time expression, it indicates the starting point in time.
  • It can also mean "to follow" or "to obey," often used in the context of professions or social roles.

Common mistakes:

  • Confusing 从 with 在 when indicating location. 从 is used for the starting point, while 在 is used for the current location.
  • Misusing 从 when referring to a continuous action or state. In such cases, other words like 一直 (yīzhí) or 始终 (shǐzhōng) are more appropriate.

无.examples:
无 (wú) without, none, not to have

  • 无聊 (wúliáo) boring, uninteresting
  • 无关 (wúguān) irrelevant, unrelated
  • 无法 (wúfǎ) unable to, cannot
  • 无论 (wúlùn) regardless of, no matter
  • 无需 (wúxū) there is no need to, unnecessary
  • 无价 (wújià) priceless, invaluable
  • 无意 (wúyì) unintentional, inadvertent

无 is a negation word that indicates the lack or absence of something. It is often used in compound words to express the idea of "without" or "not having".

Nuances:

  • When used before a verb, 无法 means "unable to" or "cannot".
  • 无需 is used to indicate that something is not necessary or required.
  • 无论 is a conjunction that means "regardless of" or "no matter".

Common mistakes:

  • Misusing 无 with nouns or adjectives where it should be replaced with 没有 (méiyǒu) or 不 (bù).
  • Confusing 无意 (unintentional) with 有意 (yǒuyì, intentional).

情.examples:
情 (qíng) feeling, emotion, sentiment, passion, desire

  • 感情 (gǎnqíng) feeling, emotion, sentiment
  • 情况 (qíngkuàng) situation, circumstances, condition
  • 情绪 (qíngxù) mood, feeling, emotional state
  • 情侣 (qínglǚ) couple, lovers
  • 情人 (qíngrén) lover, sweetheart
  • 情真意切 (qíngzhēnyìqiè) heartfelt, sincere

The character 情 is associated with emotions, feelings, and sentiments. It is often used in compound words related to interpersonal relationships, emotional states, and circumstances.

Nuances:

  • 情况 is more about the objective situation or condition, while 感情 and 情绪 refer to subjective emotions and moods.
  • 情人 and 情侣 both mean "lover" or "partner," but 情人 can also imply an extramarital affair, while 情侣 is more neutral.
  • Common mistakes include confusing 情况 with 情绪 or using 情人 when referring to a spouse or legal partner.

己.examples:
己 (jǐ) oneself, personal, individual

  • 自己 (zìjǐ) oneself, myself, yourself, etc.
  • 本人 (běnrén) oneself, myself
  • 己方 (jǐfāng) one's own side/party
  • 己见 (jǐjiàn) one's own opinion/view
  • 非己 (fēijǐ) not oneself, other than oneself

The character 己 is commonly used to express the concept of "oneself" or "one's own". It often appears in compound words related to personal perspectives, opinions, or one's own side/party.

Nuances:

  • For personal pronouns like "myself", 自己 is more commonly used than just 己.
  • In formal or written contexts, 本人 may be preferred over 己 or 自己 when referring to oneself.
  • Opposite of 己 is 非己, meaning "not oneself" or "other than oneself".

面.examples:
面 (miàn) surface, side, face, flour

  • 面包 (miànbāo) bread
  • 面条 (miàntiáo) noodles
  • 面粉 (miànfěn) flour
  • 表面 (biǎomiàn) surface, exterior
  • 面临 (miànlín) to face, to confront
  • 面积 (miànjī) area
  • 面孔 (miànkǒng) face, visage
  • 面前 (miànqián) in front of, before

The word 面 has several related meanings, with the most common being a surface, side, or face. It is also used in words related to flour-based foods like bread and noodles.

Nuances:

  • When referring to the facial features, 面孔 is more common than just 面.
  • For abstract concepts like "facing" or "confronting," 面临 is used.
  • In mathematics and geometry, 面积 is used for "area."

Common Mistakes:

  • Confusing 面包 (bread) with 包子 (steamed bun).
  • Using 面 alone when referring to facial features, instead of 面孔.

最.examples:
最 (zuì) most, the most, extremely, the most (superlative)

  • 最高 (zuìgāo) highest, maximum, supreme
  • 最低 (zuìdī) lowest, minimum
  • 最后 (zuìhòu) last, final, ultimate
  • 最近 (zuìjìn) recent, latest, lately
  • 最新 (zuìxīn) newest, latest
  • 最重要 (zuìzhòngyào) most important
  • 最好 (zuìhǎo) best

最 is used to form the superlative degree of adjectives and adverbs, indicating the highest or greatest degree of a quality or state. It can also mean "extremely" or "the most" when used with adjectives, verbs, or nouns.

Nuances:

  • When 最 precedes a verb or adjective, it often carries the meaning of "extremely" or "the most," while preceding a noun implies the superlative degree.
  • Common mistakes include using 最 with comparative adjectives or adverbs, where 更 (gèng) should be used instead.

但.examples:
但 (dàn) but, however, only, merely

  • 但是 (dànshì) but, however
  • 但不 (dànbù) but not, however not
  • 但愿 (dànyuàn) to hope, to wish for
  • 不但...而且... (bùdàn...érqiě...) not only...but also...

但 is a conjunction used to introduce a contrasting statement or idea. It can also mean "only" or "merely" in certain contexts.

Common usages and examples:

  • 我想去,但是我没有时间。I want to go, but I don't have time.
  • 他很聪明,但不努力。He is intelligent, but not hardworking.
  • 我但愿你一切都好。I hope everything is well with you.
  • 他不但英语说得很好,而且还会法语。Not only does he speak English well, but he also knows French.

Nuances and common mistakes:

  • 但是 is more common and formal than just 但 when contrasting statements.
  • Don't confuse 但愿 (to hope) with 但是 (but, however).
  • Pay attention to the word order when using 不但...而且... structure.

现.examples:
现 (xiàn) present, current, existing, visible, to show, to appear

  • 现在 (xiànzài) now, at present
  • 现状 (xiànzhuàng) current situation, present condition
  • 现场 (xiànchǎng) scene, site, location
  • 现金 (xiànjīn) cash, currency
  • 现实 (xiànshí) reality, actuality
  • 现代 (xiàndài) modern times, contemporary
  • 现象 (xiànxiàng) phenomenon, appearance
  • 显现 (xiǎnxiàn) to appear, to manifest

现 is a versatile character that often relates to the present time, current state, or something that is visible or apparent. It is commonly used in words describing existing conditions, contemporary situations, or tangible things.

Nuances and common mistakes:

  • Be careful with the tones when using 现 in different words, as the tones can change.
  • Avoid confusing 现场 (scene, location) with 现状 (current situation).
  • Note the difference between 现金 (cash) and 现钞 (paper currency).

所.examples:
所 (suǒ) can have several meanings and usages:

  • 所在 (suǒzài) location, place where something is situated
  • 例: 他所在的城市 (The city where he is located)
  • 所有 (suǒyǒu) to own, to possess
  • 例: 这是我所有的书 (These are the books I own)
  • 所以 (suǒyǐ) so, therefore, that's why
  • 例: 他生病了,所以没来上课 (He was sick, so he didn't come to class)
  • 某所 (mǒusuǒ) a certain (place)
  • 例: 他在某所大学任教 (He teaches at a certain university)
  • X所 denoting a place or organization related to X
  • 例: 医院所 (hospital), 学校所 (school)

Common mistakes:

  • Confusing 所有 (to own/possess) with 都有 (to have all/everything)
  • Misusing 所以 when the meaning is actually "where" rather than "therefore"

同.examples:
同 (tóng) same, alike, together, equal

  • 同学 (tóngxué) classmate, schoolmate
  • 同事 (tóngshì) colleague, co-worker
  • 同意 (tóngyì) to agree, to consent
  • 同情 (tóngqíng) to sympathize, to empathize
  • 同一 (tóngyī) the same, identical
  • 同时 (tóngshí) at the same time, simultaneously
  • 同样 (tóngyàng) alike, the same

同 is often used to indicate sameness, togetherness, or equality. It can be used in various compound words related to people, actions, or states that share a common trait or circumstance.

Nuances:

  • When referring to a person or people who share a certain context or situation, 同 is often combined with words like 学 (xué, study) or 事 (shì, work).
  • In some cases, 同 can also convey a sense of agreement or understanding, as in 同意 (tóngyì, to agree) and 同情 (tóngqíng, to sympathize).

Common mistakes:

  • Confusing 同 with 相同 (xiāngtóng, the same, identical). While they can be used interchangeably in some contexts, 相同 is more specific and emphasizes the exact sameness or identity of two things.

手.examples:
手 (shǒu) hand, arm

  • 手工 (shǒugōng) handmade, manual work
  • 手机 (shǒujī) mobile phone, cell phone
  • 手续 (shǒuxù) procedure, formalities
  • 手段 (shǒuduàn) means, method, trick
  • 手艺 (shǒuyì) skill, craft, workmanship
  • 手写 (shǒuxiě) handwritten
  • 手势 (shǒushì) gesture

手 is commonly used in compound words related to hands, manual work, skills, and methods. It also appears in words related to processes or procedures.

Nuances:

  • When referring to physical hands, 手 can be used alone or with a quantifier like 双手 (shuāngshǒu) meaning "both hands".
  • In some contexts, 手 can also refer to the arm, such as in 手臂 (shǒubì) meaning "arm".

Common mistakes:

  • Confusing 手续 (procedure) with 手数 (shǒushù, number of hands or attempts).
  • Mistaking 手写 (handwritten) for 手绘 (shǒuhuì, hand-drawn or hand-painted).

又.examples:
又 (yòu) again, too, both...and, also, in addition, moreover

  • 又大又圆 (yòu dà yòu yuán) both big and round
  • 再次 (zàicì) again, once more
  • 重复 (chóngfù) to repeat
  • 添加 (tiānjiā) to add, to supplement
  • 连...都... (lián...dōu...) not only...but also...

又 is an adverb that expresses repetition, addition, or enumeration. It can mean "again," "too," "also," "moreover," or "in addition." It is often used in pairs to convey the meanings "both...and..." or "not only...but also..."

Nuances:

  • When used with adjectives or verbs, 又 often needs to be repeated, e.g., 又大又圆, 又哭又闹.
  • In some cases, 又 can be replaced with 还 (hái) or 再 (zài) to express "also" or "again."
  • Be careful not to overuse 又 in formal writing, as it can make the language sound too conversational.

Common mistakes:

  • Misusing 又 with nouns or pronouns instead of adjectives or verbs, e.g., *又他又她 (should be 他和她).
  • Omitting 又 in constructions like 大圆 (should be 又大又圆).

行.examples:
行 (xíng) row, line, travel, walk, go, operate, do, OK

  • 行业 (xíngyè) industry, trade, line of business
  • 行为 (xíngwéi) behavior, conduct, action
  • 出行 (chūxíng) to go out, to travel
  • 步行 (bùxíng) to walk, to go on foot
  • 运行 (yùnxíng) to operate, to run (a program)
  • 可行 (kěxíng) feasible, viable, practicable
  • 行人 (xíngrén) pedestrian, walker
  • 银行 (yínháng) bank

行 has a wide range of meanings, often related to movement, action, or the way something is done or operates. It is commonly used in compound words to indicate industries, behaviors, or processes.

Nuances:

  • When referring to going somewhere or traveling, 去 (qù) is more common than 行 in everyday speech.
  • In the context of "OK" or "all right," 行 is often used in response to instructions or requests.
  • Common mistakes include confusing 行业 (industry) with 行为 (behavior).

意.examples:
意 (yì) thought, idea, desire, intention, meaning

  • 意见 (yìjiàn) opinion, view, suggestion
  • 意识 (yìshí) consciousness, awareness
  • 意味 (yìwèi) to imply, to suggest, to mean
  • 意图 (yìtú) intention, intent, purpose
  • 意义 (yìyì) meaning, significance, importance
  • 意愿 (yìyuàn) desire, wish, willingness
  • 意外 (yìwài) accidental, unexpected

意 relates to thoughts, ideas, intentions, and meanings. It often appears in compound words related to mental concepts or states of mind.

Nuances:

  • When expressing an opinion, 意见 is more common than just 意.
  • 意味 suggests an implied or subtle meaning, while 意义 refers to the explicit or apparent meaning.
  • Be careful with the word order when using 意 in compound words, as the meaning can change depending on the order of characters.

Common mistakes:

  • Confusing 意识 (consciousness) with 意识到 (to realize, to become aware).
  • Misusing 意外 (accidental) with 意想不到 (unexpected, unimaginable).

动.examples:
动 (dòng) verb, to move, to budge, to start

  • 动作 (dòngzuò) movement, motion, action
  • 动词 (dòngcí) verb
  • 运动 (yùndòng) exercise, motion, movement
  • 动员 (dòngyuán) to mobilize, to motivate
  • 动物 (dòngwù) animal
  • 动力 (dònglì) motive power, driving force
  • 动情 (dòngqíng) to be moved emotionally

动 is a versatile word that can mean "to move" or "to start" in a physical or abstract sense. It is often used in compound words related to motion, action, and change.

Nuances:

  • When referring to physical movement, 动作 or 运动 are more common than just 动.
  • 动词 specifically refers to verbs in grammar.
  • 动员 implies mobilizing or motivating people or resources.
  • 动情 refers to being emotionally moved or touched.

Common mistakes:

  • Confusing 动物 (animal) with 植物 (plant).
  • Using 动 alone when a more specific term like 动作 or 运动 is more appropriate.

方.examples:
方 (fāng) direction, side, square, square measure, local, regional

  • 方向 (fāngxiàng) direction
  • 四方 (sìfāng) all directions, all around
  • 方式 (fāngshì) way, method, manner
  • 方法 (fāngfǎ) method, way
  • 方面 (fāngmiàn) aspect, field, respect
  • 方程 (fāngchéng) equation
  • 方块 (fāngkuài) square, block
  • 方言 (fāngyán) dialect, local speech

The character 方 is often used in words related to directions, ways/methods, aspects/fields, and geometry. It can also refer to something being local or regional.

Nuances:

  • When referring to a specific method or way of doing something, 方法 is more common than just 方式.
  • 方面 is often used when discussing different aspects or fields, while 方向 is more specific to physical directions.
  • In the context of geometry, 方块 is a square or block shape, while 方程 is specifically an equation.

期.examples:
期 (qī) period, time, date, issue, to expect

  • 期限 (qīxiàn) time limit, deadline
  • 期望 (qīwàng) to hope for, to expect
  • 期间 (qījiān) period, duration, time
  • 期刊 (qīkān) periodical, journal, magazine
  • 本期 (běnqī) this issue, this installment
  • 下期 (xiàqī) next issue, next installment
  • 期末 (qīmò) end of term, end of semester
  • 期中 (qīzhōng) midterm, middle of a period

期 is a versatile character that often relates to time periods, deadlines, expectations, or issues of periodicals. It can be used as a noun, verb, or measure word.

Nuances:

  • When referring to a specific issue of a magazine or journal, 期 is often followed by an ordinal number (e.g., 第三期 dì sān qī "third issue").
  • In the context of exams or academic terms, 期末 and 期中 are commonly used.
  • A common mistake is confusing 期望 (to expect, to hope for) with 希望 (to hope, to wish).

头.examples:
头 (tóu) head, top, beginning, chief, leader

  • 头发 (tóufa) hair
  • 头痛 (tóutòng) headache
  • 头一次 (tóuyīcì) for the first time
  • 头等 (tóudeng) first-class, top-grade
  • 头领 (tóulǐng) leader, chief
  • 头脑 (tóunǎo) mind, brain
  • 头上 (tóushàng) on the head, above
  • 头目 (tóumù) leader, chief, boss

The word 头 has various meanings and usages related to the physical head, as well as metaphorical meanings referring to the beginning, top, or leadership.

Nuances:

  • When referring to hair, 头发 is more common than just 头.
  • 头痛 is a common expression for "headache," while 头疼 (tóuténg) is also used in some regions.
  • In compound words like 头等 and 头领, 头 implies superiority or leadership.

Common mistakes:

  • Misusing 头 for "brain" instead of 头脑.
  • Confusing the order of words, e.g., saying 上头 instead of 头上.

经.examples:
经 (jīng) classics, scripture, sacred book; to pass through, undergo, experience; chief, principal; channel, pathway

  • 经典 (jīngdiǎn) classic, masterpiece
  • 经历 (jīnglì) experience, go through
  • 经营 (jīngyíng) to operate, manage, run a business
  • 经济 (jīngjì) economy, economic
  • 经常 (jīngcháng) frequent, often
  • 经过 (jīngguò) to go through, pass through, undergo
  • 经纬 (jīngwěi) warp and woof, longitude and latitude

The word 经 has a variety of meanings and usages in Chinese, often related to:

  • Classic texts, scriptures or important works
  • Undergoing or experiencing something
  • Management, operation or running of affairs
  • Economic or financial matters
  • Pathways, channels or spatial coordinates

Common mistakes:

  • Confusing 经历 (experience) and 经验 (experience, expertise)
  • Mixing up 经常 (often) and 常常 (often)
  • Using 经过 incorrectly with locations (e.g., 经过北京 should be 路过北京)

长.examples:
长 (zhǎng) long, grow, leader

  • 长度 (chángdù) length
  • 长期 (chángqī) long-term
  • 长大 (zhǎngdà) to grow up
  • 长辈 (zhǎngbèi) elders, seniors
  • 长官 (zhǎngguān) superior, leader
  • 长途 (chángtú) long-distance
  • 长城 (Chángchéng) Great Wall

长 can be used to describe length, duration, or growth. It can also indicate seniority or leadership positions. Some common usages include:

  • 长度 refers to the physical length of an object.
  • 长期 describes something that lasts for a long time.
  • 长大 means to grow up or become an adult.
  • 长辈 refers to elders or senior members of a family or group.
  • 长官 is a superior or leader in a hierarchical organization.

Nuances:

  • When describing physical length, 长 is often combined with a measure word, e.g., 三米长 (three meters long).
  • In the context of time or duration, 长期 is more commonly used than just 长.
  • Be careful not to confuse 长 (grow) with 张 (measure word for flat objects, e.g., 一张桌子 (one table)).

儿.examples:
儿 (ér) son, child, masculine diminutive suffix

  • 儿子 (érzi) son
  • 孩儿 (hái'r) child
  • 小儿 (xiǎo'ér) child, infant
  • 老儿 (lǎo'ér) old man, old fellow
  • 娃儿 (wá'r) baby, infant

儿 is often used as a suffix to indicate:

  • Diminutive or endearment, e.g., 猫儿 (māo'r) kitty, 盘儿 (pán'r) small plate
  • Emphasis or informality, e.g., 房儿 (fáng'r) room, 桌儿 (zhuō'r) table

Common mistakes:

  • Forgetting to use the neutral tone (light tone) when it's a suffix
  • Using 儿 with words that are already diminutive, e.g., *小猫儿 (xiǎomāo'r)
  • Over-using the diminutive suffix, which can sound unnatural or childish in some contexts

位.examples:
位 (wèi) measure word for people, location, position

  • 一位老师 (yī wèi lǎoshī) a teacher
  • 这位先生 (zhè wèi xiānsheng) this gentleman
  • 前位 (qiánwèi) predecessor, former position
  • 高位 (gāowèi) high position, high ranking
  • 位置 (wèizhi) location, position

位 is commonly used as a measure word for people, especially in formal or respectful contexts. It can also indicate a position, rank, or location.

Nuances:

  • When referring to a specific person, 位 is more polite and formal than not using a measure word.
  • 位 is often used with titles or professions, but not always with kinship terms like 爸爸 (bàba, father) or 妈妈 (māma, mother).
  • In certain contexts, 位 can have a sense of hierarchy or status, as in 高位 (gāowèi, high position).

Common mistakes:

  • Using 位 with inanimate objects or concepts. For example, "一位问题" is incorrect; you would say "一个问题" (yīgè wèntí, a question/problem).
  • Omitting 位 when referring to a specific person in formal or polite contexts, which can be seen as impolite.

分.examples:
分 (fēn) divide, part, share, distribute, minute (of time), point (on a scale)

  • 分开 (fēnkāi) to separate, to divide
  • 分手 (fēnshǒu) to break up, to split up
  • 分数 (fēnshù) fraction, score
  • 分类 (fēnlèi) to classify, to categorize
  • 分担 (fēndān) to share (a burden)
  • 分钟 (fēnzhōng) minute
  • 分散 (fēnsàn) to scatter, to disperse

分 often represents the act of dividing, separating, or categorizing something. It can also refer to fractions, scores, or units of time like minutes. The meaning of 分 is highly context-dependent.

Nuances:

  • When referring to time, 分钟 is the standard way to say "minute(s)".
  • In mathematical contexts, 分数 is used for "fraction".
  • For sharing burdens or responsibilities, 分担 is more common than just 分.

Common mistakes:

  • Confusing 分手 (to break up) with 分开 (to separate). They have different implications.
  • Using 分 alone when a more specific compound word like 分类 or 分散 is more appropriate.

老.examples:
老 (lǎo) old, aged, elderly, experienced

  • 老人 (lǎorén) elderly person, old person
  • 老师 (lǎoshī) teacher
  • 老板 (lǎobǎn) boss, employer
  • 老朋友 (lǎo péngyǒu) old friend
  • 老家 (lǎojiā) native place, hometown
  • 老伴 (lǎobàn) spouse, partner in life
  • 老实 (lǎoshí) honest, sincere
  • 老年 (lǎonián) old age

老 is often used as a prefix to indicate age, experience, or seniority. It can also denote respect when used before certain titles or relationships.

Nuances:

  • Using 老 alone without a noun can be informal or impolite when referring to someone's age.
  • In some contexts, 老 can also mean "very familiar with" or "experienced in," as in 老手 (lǎoshǒu) meaning "veteran" or "expert."
  • When used before a family name, 老 can indicate respect or familiarity, but it's important to use it appropriately based on the relationship and context.

Common mistakes:

  • Overusing 老 to refer to someone's age in formal or unfamiliar contexts, which can be seen as impolite or disrespectful.
  • Misusing 老 with certain titles or relationships where it's not appropriate or common usage.

因.examples:
因 (yīn) because, due to, cause, origin

  • 原因 (yuányīn) reason, cause
  • 理由 (lǐyóu) reason
  • 缘故 (yuángù) reason, cause
  • 由于 (yóuyú) due to, owing to, because of
  • 因为 (yīnwèi) because, due to
  • 起因 (qǐyīn) cause, origin

因 is used to express causality, reasons, or origins. It is often paired with other words to form compound phrases.

Nuances and common mistakes:

  • When expressing a reason, 因为 is more commonly used in spoken Chinese, while 由于 is more formal and written.
  • Be careful with word order when using 因为. The structure is 因为...所以... ("Because... therefore...") and not the opposite.
  • When referring to the cause or origin of something, 起因 is more common than just 因.

给.examples:
给 (gěi) verb, preposition

  • 给予 (gěiyǔ) to give, to offer
  • 给予支持 (gěiyǔ zhīchí) to give support
  • 给予机会 (gěiyǔ jīhuì) to give an opportunity
  • 给他们 (gěi tāmen) to/for them
  • 给我看 (gěi wǒ kàn) let me see
  • 给予帮助 (gěiyǔ bāngzhù) to give help

给 is a verb meaning "to give" and a preposition used to indicate the recipient of an action or object. It's often followed by a noun or pronoun.

Common Mistakes:

  • Omitting 给 before the recipient when giving something.
  • Confusing the verb 给 (to give) with 跟 (with, and).

Nuances:

  • 给 can be combined with other verbs to form more specific expressions, like 给予支持 (to give support).
  • When used as a preposition, 给 indicates the recipient of an action or object, like 给他们 (to/for them).

名.examples:
名 (míng) noun, family name

  • 姓名 (xìngmíng) full name
  • 有名 (yǒumíng) famous, well-known
  • 名称 (míngchēng) name, title, designation
  • 名词 (míngcí) noun
  • 名人 (míngrén) famous person, celebrity

名 is often used in compound words related to names, titles, or referring to something by name. It can also indicate fame or reputation.

Nuances:

  • When referring to a person's full name, 姓名 is more common than just 名.
  • In formal or official contexts, 姓名 or 名称 is preferred over 名.

法.examples:
法 (fǎ) law, method, way, Buddhism

  • 法律 (fǎlǜ) law, legal
  • 方法 (fāngfǎ) method, way
  • 法规 (fǎguī) regulation, rule
  • 法院 (fǎyuàn) court
  • 佛法 (fófǎ) Buddhist teachings
  • 法则 (fǎzé) principle, rule
  • 法令 (fǎlìng) order, decree

法 is a versatile character that can refer to laws, regulations, methods, principles, or Buddhist teachings. It is often used in compound words related to legal, judicial, or procedural contexts.

Nuances:

  • In the legal context, 法律 refers to laws, while 法规 refers to regulations or rules.
  • 方法 specifically means 'method' or 'way,' while 法 alone can also mean 'method' but in a broader sense.
  • In Buddhist contexts, 佛法 refers to the teachings of Buddhism.

Common mistakes:

  • Confusing 法律 (law) and 法规 (regulation) when referring to legal matters.
  • Using 法 alone when a more specific term like 方法 (method) or 法则 (principle) is more appropriate.

间.examples:
间 (jiān) room, space, period of time, interval

  • 房间 (fángjiān) room
  • 空间 (kōngjiān) space
  • 时间 (shíjiān) time, period
  • 间隔 (jiāngé) interval, gap
  • 中间 (zhōngjiān) middle, intermediate
  • 之间 (zhījiān) between, among

The character 间 has various meanings related to physical spaces, rooms, and time intervals. It is often used in compound words to indicate a space or period of time.

Nuances:

  • When referring to a physical room, 房间 is more common than just 间.
  • 空间 generally refers to a broader concept of space, while 间 is more specific to rooms or enclosed spaces.
  • For time intervals, 时间 is often used in combination with 间, such as 一个小时的时间间隔 (a one-hour time interval).

Common mistakes:

  • Using 间 alone to mean "room" can be ambiguous and is generally avoided in formal contexts.
  • Confusing 之间 (between) with 中间 (middle, intermediate) when describing relationships or positions.

见.examples:
见 (jiàn) verb, to see, to meet, to visit

  • 见面 (jiànmiàn) to meet, to get together
  • 看见 (kànjiàn) to see, to catch sight of
  • 见过 (jiànguò) to have seen, to have experienced
  • 见识 (jiànshì) knowledge, experience, insights
  • 见解 (jiàn​jiě) opinion, view, perspective
  • 见证 (jiànzhèng) to witness, to be a witness to
  • 见义勇为 (jiànyìyǒngwéi) to bravely uphold justice in the face of adversity

The verb 见 is commonly used to express seeing, meeting, or encountering someone or something. It can also mean to gain experience or insight, as well as to witness or understand something.

Nuances:

  • When combined with certain complements, it can take on additional meanings, such as 看见 (to see) or 见面 (to meet).
  • It can be used in idioms or set phrases, such as 见义勇为 (to bravely uphold justice).
  • Common mistakes include misusing 看见 and 见, which have slightly different connotations (seeing vs. encountering).

知.examples:
知 (zhī) to know, to be aware of

  • 知识 (zhīshí) knowledge
  • 知道 (zhīdao) to know, to be aware of
  • 知名 (zhīmíng) well-known, famous
  • 知情 (zhīqíng) to be informed, to have information
  • 知己 (zhījǐ) intimate friend, bosom friend
  • 知觉 (zhījué) perception, sensation

The character 知 is often used in words related to knowledge, awareness, or understanding. It can also imply familiarity or recognition.

Nuances:

  • 知道 is the most common way to express "to know" something.
  • When referring to knowledge or information, 知识 is more widely used than just 知.
  • 知名 and 知情 imply being well-known or well-informed, respectively.

Common mistakes:

  • Using 知 on its own to mean "to know" without a complement, which sounds incomplete.
  • Confusing 知名 (well-known) with 有名 (famous).

世.examples:
世 (shì) generation, era, world, lifetime

  • 世界 (shìjiè) world, globe
  • 世代 (shìdài) generation, age
  • 世纪 (shìjì) century
  • 世故 (shìgù) worldly, experienced
  • 世人 (shìrén) people of the world, everybody
  • 世俗 (shìsú) secular, worldly

The character 世 is often used in words related to the world, generations, eras, or lifetimes. It can refer to the physical world, the people in the world, or the passage of time through generations and centuries.

Nuances:

  • When referring to the physical world or globe, 世界 is the most common word.
  • 世代 and 世纪 are used for different time scales, with 世代 referring to generations or ages, and 世纪 specifically meaning a century.
  • 世故 and 世俗 have a slightly negative connotation, implying being too worldly or secular.

Common mistakes:

  • Confusing 世代 (generation) and 世纪 (century).
  • Using 世 alone to mean "world" when 世界 is more appropriate.

什.examples:
什 (shén) what, particle for indicating plurality

  • 什么 (shénme) what
  • 什么人 (shénmerén) what kind of person
  • 什么东西 (shénmedōngxi) what thing
  • 什么时候 (shénmeshíhou) when
  • 什么地方 (shénmedìfang) where
  • 什么样 (shénmeyàng) what kind, what sort

什 is a bound morpheme that cannot stand alone and must be combined with other words. When combined with 么 (me) to form 什么, it serves as an interrogative pronoun meaning "what."

Common mistakes:

  • Using 什 alone without the suffix 么 is incorrect.
  • Confusing 什么 with 哪 (nǎ) when asking about location or time. 哪 is used for "where" and "when," while 什么 is used for "what."

两.examples:
两 (liǎng) two, both, a couple

  • 两个 (liǎnggè) two (for counting)
  • 两年 (liǎngnián) two years
  • 两者 (liǎngzhě) both parties, both of them
  • 两边 (liǎngbiān) both sides, two sides
  • 两种 (liǎngzhǒng) two kinds, two types
  • 两人 (liǎngrén) two people

两 is a number word meaning "two" and is frequently used as a measure word or in compound words to indicate two of something. It can also mean "both" when referring to two parties or sides.

Nuances:

  • When used before a measure word or noun, 两 is often combined with 个 (gè) to form 两个.
  • In certain contexts, 两 can be used alone without a measure word, such as 两年 (two years) or 两人 (two people).
  • Common mistakes include using 两 alone when a measure word is required, or using 两个 before nouns that have their own specific measure words.

次.examples:
次 (cì) time, occurrence, order, sequence

  • 第一次 (dì yī cì) first time, for the first time
  • 重复次数 (chóngfù cìshù) number of repetitions
  • 几次 (jǐ cì) how many times
  • 一次又一次 (yī cì yóu yī cì) time and again, repeatedly
  • 次序 (cìxù) order, sequence

次 is often used to indicate the frequency or order of an event or action. It can also refer to the sequence or ranking of something.

Nuances:

  • When referring to a specific number of times, 次 is usually preceded by a number, e.g., 三次 (sān cì) three times.
  • In some cases, 次数 (cìshù) number of times is used instead of just 次 for clarity.
  • Common mistakes involve confusing 次 with 第 (dì) ordinal number when referring to the order of things.

明.examples:
明 (míng) bright, light, next, understand, dynasty

  • 明天 (mingtian) tomorrow
  • 明白 (mingbai) to understand, to comprehend
  • 明亮 (mingliang) bright, brilliant
  • 明确 (mingque) clear, definite, explicit
  • 明年 (mingnian) next year
  • 明显 (mingxian) obvious, evident, conspicuous
  • 明朗 (minglang) bright, clear, lucid
  • 明智 (mingzhi) wise, sensible, judicious
  • 明династía (Ming Chao) Ming Dynasty (1368-1644)

The character 明 has multiple meanings, but they generally revolve around the concepts of brightness, clarity, understanding, and the next day/year. It is often used in compound words related to these concepts.

Nuances:

  • When referring to the next day, 明天 is more common than just 明.
  • In the context of understanding or comprehension, 明白 is the most common usage.
  • The Ming Dynasty is typically referred to as 明朝 (Ming Chao) rather than just 明.

Common mistakes:

  • Confusing 明 with 名 (míng, name) due to their similar pronunciations.
  • Using 明 incorrectly in contexts where it should be replaced with a more specific compound word (e.g., 明白 for understanding, 明亮 for brightness).

身.examples:
身 (shēn) body, physical form, person

  • 身体 (shēntǐ) body, physique, health
  • 身高 (shēngāo) height
  • 身材 (shēncái) figure, physique, build
  • 身份 (shēnfèn) identity, status, capacity
  • 身边 (shēnbiān) around, by one's side
  • 身上 (shēnshang) on one's body, on oneself
  • 亲身 (qīnshēn) in person, personally

身 is commonly used in words related to the body, physical appearance, health, and personal identity or status. It can also indicate proximity or personal experience.

Nuances:

  • When referring to the physical body, 身体 is more commonly used than just 身.
  • For describing someone's figure or physique, 身材 is the preferred term.
  • In formal or official contexts, 身份 is used to refer to one's identity or status.
  • Common mistakes include using 身高 to mean "weight" instead of "height."

者.examples:
者 (zhě) suffix indicating a person or thing

  • 作者 (zuòzhě) author, writer
  • 读者 (dúzhě) reader
  • 观众 (guānzhòng) audience, spectators
  • 工作者 (gōngzuòzhě) worker
  • 旅行者 (lǚxíngzhě) traveler
  • 学者 (xuézhě) scholar, academic

者 is a suffix added to verbs or nouns to indicate a person or thing associated with that action or concept. It is often used to form words referring to different types of people or roles.

Nuances:

  • Some words with 者 have synonyms without it (e.g. 作家 for 作者).
  • Words with 者 tend to feel more formal or literary compared to their synonyms.
  • Common mistakes include using 者 incorrectly with words where it doesn't belong.

被.examples:
被 (bèi) passive particle, accusative marker

  • 被打 (bèi dǎ) to be hit, to be beaten
  • 被遗忘 (bèi yíwàng) to be forgotten
  • 被捕 (bèi bǔ) to be arrested
  • 被毁 (bèi huǐ) to be destroyed
  • 被褥 (bèilǚ) bedding, bedclothes

被 is a particle used to indicate the passive voice in a sentence. It marks the object that receives the action expressed by the verb. It can also function as an accusative marker, indicating the direct object of a verb.

Nuances:

  • The passive voice formed with 被 is more formal and literary compared to the more colloquial 让 passive structure.
  • In some cases, 被 can also be used as a noun, meaning "bedding" or "bedclothes" as in 被褥.
  • Common mistakes include using 被 with intransitive verbs or with verbs that don't allow the passive voice.

已.examples:
已 (yǐ) already, past tense marker

  • 已经 (yǐjīng) already, previously, by now
  • 已完成 (yǐwánchéng) already completed, finished
  • 已过去 (yǐguòqù) already passed, gone
  • 已知 (yǐzhī) already known, given
  • 已婚 (yǐhūn) married

已 is commonly used as a marker for the past tense or to indicate that an action has already happened or been completed. It is often used with other verbs or adjectives to express this meaning.

Nuances:

  • 已经 is more commonly used than just 已 alone to express the past tense or completed action.
  • When used alone, 已 can sometimes have a more emphatic or definitive tone compared to 已经.
  • In some compound words like 已婚 (married), 已 can take on a slightly different meaning of "having become" or "having entered into" a state.

Common mistakes:

  • Forgetting to use 已 or 已经 when referring to past or completed actions in Chinese.
  • Using 已 instead of 已经 in more casual or informal contexts, where 已经 is more natural.

问.examples:
问 (wèn) to ask, to inquire, to question

  • 问题 (wèntí) question, problem, issue
  • 提问 (tíwèn) to ask a question, to raise a question
  • 回答问题 (huídá wèntí) to answer a question
  • 问候 (wènhòu) to greet, to send regards
  • 问路 (wènlù) to ask for directions
  • 问世 (wènshì) to be born, to come into the world

The word 问 is primarily used to express the action of asking a question or inquiring about something. It is commonly found in compound words related to questioning, problems, and inquiries.

Nuances:

  • 问 is more formal and polite than 请教 (qǐngjiào), which also means "to ask" but has a more humble tone.
  • 问 can also be used in the sense of seeking information or clarification, not just asking questions directly.
  • Certain combinations like 问世 and 问候 have idiomatic meanings that go beyond the literal sense of "to ask".

Common mistakes:

  • Using 问 when the context calls for a more polite or humble way of asking, such as in formal situations or when addressing elders or superiors.
  • Confusing 问 with 闻 (wén), which means "to hear" or "to smell".

其.examples:
其 (qí) its, his, her, that, those, the aforementioned

  • 其他 (qítā) other, the rest
  • 其中 (qízhōng) among them, therein, in that
  • 其实 (qíshí) actually, in fact
  • 其次 (qícì) second, next
  • 其间 (qíjiān) in the meantime, during that time
  • 其后 (qíhòu) after that, afterwards

其 is a pronoun that refers to something or someone previously mentioned, often translated as "it," "its," "his," "her," "that," or "those." It is commonly used in compound words to indicate a relationship or reference to something mentioned earlier.

Nuances:

  • When 其 is used alone, it usually refers to a previously mentioned noun or context.
  • In formal or written Chinese, 其 is often used instead of personal pronouns like "他," "她," "它" for a more formal tone.
  • Common mistakes include confusing 其他 (other) with 另外 (another) or 其次 (second) with 第二 (second).

进.examples:
进 (jìn) to enter, to advance, to make progress

  • 进入 (jìnrù) to enter, to get into
  • 进步 (jìnbù) to make progress, to improve
  • 进来 (jìnlái) to come in, to enter
  • 进去 (jìnqu) to go in, to enter
  • 进展 (jìnzhǎn) to make progress, development
  • 进攻 (jìngōng) to attack, offensive
  • 进口 (jìnkǒu) to import
  • 进程 (jìnchéng) process, progression

The character 进 is commonly used to indicate movement or action in a forward direction, whether physical or abstract. It can also convey the idea of progress, improvement, or development.

Nuances and Common Mistakes:

  • When used with directional complements like 来 (lái) or 去 (qù), 进 specifies the direction of the action.
  • Be cautious with the word order when using 进 in compound words, as it can change the meaning (e.g., 进口 means "to import," while 口进 is not a valid word).
  • Avoid confusing 进 with 近 (jìn), which means "near" or "close."

此.examples:
此 (cǐ) this, the present

  • 此时 (cǐshí) this time, now
  • 此外 (cǐwài) besides this, in addition
  • 此刻 (cǐkè) this moment, now
  • 此处 (cǐchù) this place, here
  • 此间 (cǐjiān) here, this place
  • 此中 (cǐzhōng) within this, herein
  • 如此 (rúcǐ) like this, in this way

此 is a demonstrative pronoun used to refer to something in the present or nearby context. It often combines with other words to form set phrases indicating time, place, or manner.

Nuances:

  • 此 typically refers to things in the present or nearby context, while 那 (nà) refers to things further away or in the past/future.
  • In formal or literary writing, 此 is more common than 这 (zhè) for referring to present things.
  • Common mistakes include using 此 with words related to the past or future, such as *此年 (intended meaning: "that year") or *此天 (intended meaning: "that day").

话.examples:
话 (huà) word, speech, language, dialect

  • 说话 (shuōhuà) to speak, to talk
  • 话题 (huàtí) topic, subject
  • 对话 (duìhuà) dialogue, conversation
  • 语言 (yǔyán) language
  • 方言 (fāngyán) dialect, local speech
  • 闲话 (xiánhuà) idle talk, gossip
  • 话语 (huàyǔ) speech, words

话 is a versatile word that can refer to spoken language, words, or a specific language or dialect. It is often used in compound words related to communication, speech, and language.

Nuances:

  • 语言 is more formal and refers to a specific language system, while 话 can be more colloquial and refer to speech or dialect.
  • In the context of a conversation, 话题 refers to the topic or subject being discussed, while 对话 refers to the dialogue or exchange itself.
  • Certain compounds like 闲话 or 话语 can have slightly different connotations or usages depending on the context.

常.examples:
常 (cháng)

  • 常常 (chángcháng) often, frequently
  • 常规 (chánggुī) regular, normal, routine
  • 常识 (chángshí) common sense
  • 常见 (chángjiàn) common, frequently seen
  • 不常 (bùcháng) not often, seldom
  • 经常 (jīngcháng) often, frequently

The character 常 is often used to indicate frequency, regularity, or something that is common or normal. It can be used as an adverb to describe the frequency of an action or as an adjective to describe something that is regular or common.

Nuances:

  • 常常 and 经常 are more colloquial ways to express frequency, while 常见 is more formal.
  • 常规 often refers to established rules or norms.
  • 常识 is used to refer to common knowledge or general understanding of things.

Common mistakes:

  • Overusing 常常 or 经常 in formal writing, when a more concise term like 常 or 频繁 would be more appropriate.
  • Confusing 常 with 张 (zhāng, a measure word for flat objects) due to their similar pronunciations.

与.examples:
与 (yǔ) with, and, together with, to give

  • 与他合作 (yǔ tā hézuò) to cooperate with him
  • 朋友与家人 (péngyou yǔ jiārén) friends and family
  • 你与我 (nǐ yǔ wǒ) you and I
  • 与其等待,不如行动 (yǔ qí děngdài, bùrú xíngdòng) rather than waiting, it's better to take action
  • 与别人分享 (yǔ biérén fēnxiǎng) to share with others

与 is a conjunction used to connect two or more subjects, objects, or ideas. It can also mean "to give" in certain contexts.

Nuances:

  • When connecting two subjects or objects, 与 implies a closer or more equal relationship than 和 (hé).
  • In comparisons, 与 is often used with 其 (qí) to mean "rather than."
  • Be careful not to confuse 与 with 予 (yǔ), which means "to give" but is rarely used in modern Chinese.

活.examples:
活 (huó) alive, living, active, movable

  • 活着 (huózhe) to be alive, to live
  • 生活 (shēnghuó) life, living, livelihood
  • 活动 (huódòng) activity, move about, exercise
  • 活力 (huólì) vigor, vitality, energy
  • 活跃 (huóyuè) vigorous, active, lively
  • 活泼 (huópō) lively, vivacious, energetic
  • 活路 (huólù) way out, a means of survival

The character 活 is related to concepts of being alive, full of life, and active. It can be used to describe living beings, liveliness, movement, or a means of sustenance.

Nuances:

  • In the context of surviving or making a living, 活路 or 生活 is often used.
  • For describing a lively or energetic person or atmosphere, 活泼 or 活力 is more common.
  • When referring to physical activities or events, 活动 is the typical choice.

Common Mistakes:

  • Confusing 活 with 火 (fire) due to their similar pronunciations.
  • Using 活着 incorrectly in contexts where 生存 (to exist, to survive) would be more appropriate.

正.examples:
正 (zhèng)

  • 正确 (zhèngquè) correct, right, accurate
  • 正直 (zhèngzhí) upright, honest, righteous
  • 正面 (zhèngmiàn) front, obverse, positive
  • 正常 (zhèngcháng) normal, regular, ordinary
  • 正在 (zhèngzài) in the process of, currently
  • 正月 (zhēngyuè) first month of the lunar calendar

The character 正 has several meanings and usages:

  • It can indicate correctness, accuracy, or righteousness, as in 正确 (correct) and 正直 (upright).
  • It can refer to the front, obverse, or positive side of something, as in 正面 (front side).
  • It can mean normal, regular, or ordinary, as in 正常 (normal).
  • It can indicate the present or ongoing action when used with 在, as in 正在 (in the process of).
  • It can also refer to the first month of the lunar calendar, as in 正月 (first month).

Nuances and common mistakes:

  • When expressing correctness or accuracy, 正确 is more common than just 正.
  • Be careful with the tones, as 正 has a rising tone (zhèng), while 正月 has a neutral tone (zhēng).
  • Avoid using 正 alone when referring to the front or obverse side; 正面 is more appropriate.

感.examples:
感 (gǎn) sense, feeling, emotion, to sense, to feel

  • 感觉 (gǎnjué) feeling, sense, perception
  • 感冒 (gǎnmào) to catch a cold
  • 感动 (gǎndòng) to be moved, touched
  • 感谢 (gǎnxiè) to thank, to be grateful
  • 感受 (gǎnshòu) to experience, to perceive
  • 感想 (gǎnxiǎng) thoughts, reflections
  • 感染 (gǎnrǎn) to infect, to contract (a disease)

感 is often used in words related to feelings, emotions, and sensory experiences. It can also indicate contracting an illness or being affected by something.

Nuances:

  • When expressing gratitude, 感谢 is more commonly used than just 感.
  • For catching a cold or other illnesses, 感冒 is a set phrase, while 感染 is more general.
  • When talking about impressions or reflections, 感想 is more appropriate than just 感.

Common Mistakes:

  • Confusing 感觉 (feeling) with 感受 (to experience). While related, they have slightly different nuances.
  • Using 感 alone when a compound word would be more appropriate, e.g., 感冒 for "catch a cold" instead of just 感.
